title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: Martha was happy at the thought of passing her days in the Highlands, somewhere in the Glen of Dee, or in Glen Tilt, or on the banks of the Bruar, or by the waterfalls of the Tummel, or the sylvan shores of Loch Bannoch.

title: Noctes ambrosianæ,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: Dr. Morris, Wastle, and Odoherty, each attended by a Highland guide, provided for them, as we have said, by the munificence of the Thane, took their departure to the mountains ; the Dr. ascending the pass of the Geonly Water, with a view to the ground towards the head of Glen Tilt, Wastle taking up the glen of the source of the Dee, and the Adjutant meditating a cast or two with our own favorite bitch, over the ground behind Mar-Lodge.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: We drove along Glen Tilt, through a wood over-hanging the river Tilt, which joins the Garry, and as we left the wood we came upon such a lovely view, — Bcn-y-GJilo straight before us — and under these high hills the river Tilt gushing and winding over stones and slates, and the hills and mountains skirted at the bottom with beautiful trees ; the whole lit up by the sun ; and the air so pure and fine ; but no description can at all do it justice, or eive an idea of what this drive was.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: Wedrove up by the avenue and about a favorite walkof ours in '44, passed through the gate, and cameon to Glen Tilt, which is most striking, the roadwinding along first on one side of the Tilt, andthen on the other ; the fine high hiUs rising veryabruptly from each side of the rapid, rocky, stonyRiver Tilt — ^the trees, chiefly birch and alder, overhanging the water.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: As we approached Lnchrory (a shooting-lodge of Lord H. Bentinck's) the scenery becamefiner and finer, reminding us of Glen Tilt, and wasmost beautiful at Lnchrory, with the fine broadwater of the Avon flowing down from the mountains.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: We went by a very wUd and lonely road,the latter part extremely fine, with mountainsand streams that reminded us of Glen Tilt.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: At twenty minutes to elevenwe drove off with Lady Canning for Glen Tilt.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: At fouro'clock I set off with Lady Glenlyon and LadyCanning, Mr. Oswald and Lord Charles Wellesleyriding, by the lower Glen Tilt drive.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: We drovealong Glen Tilt, through a wood overhanging theRiver Tilt, which joins the Ga/rry, and as we leftthe wood we came upon such a lovely view —Ben-y-Ghlo straight before us — and under thesehigh hUls the River Tilt gushing and windingover stones and slates, and the hUls and mountains skirted at the bottom with beautiful trees —the whole Ut up by the sun — and the air so pureand fine ; but no description can at all do it justice, or give an idea of what this drive was.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: It was half-pasttwelve — we drove up by the avenue and abouta favourite walk of ours in '44, passed through thegate, and came on to Glen Tilt — which is moststriking, the road winding along, first on one sideof the Tilt, and then on the other ; the fine highhills rising very abruptly from each side of therapid, rocky, stony river Tilt — the trees, chieflybirch and alder, overhanging the water.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: We drovealong Glen Tilt, through a wood over-hanging theriver Tilt, which joins the Garry, and as weleft the wood we came upon such a lovely view,— Ben-y-Ghlo straight before us — and under thesehigh hills the river Tilt gushing and winding overstones and slates, and the hills and mountainsskirted at the bottom with beautiful trees ; thewhole lit up by the sun ; and the air so pure andfine; but no description can at all do it justice,or give an idea of what this drive was.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Glen Tilt is bounded on each side by the steep flanks of lofty hills.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: From Blair-Atholl, a road much travelled by pedestrians during summer leads through Glen Tilt, and over a wild mountainous district, to Braemar, 30 miles, taking from 11 to 12 hours' good walking.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The opening of Glen Tilt, branching off, dark and deep, with all its closing woods, forms an important feature in the view, stretching far away into the mountains, and displaying, in towering succession, the huge masses of Ben-y-Gloe, with the fine conical and undulating forms of the lofty hills that extend wide over the northern part

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The tourist entering Glen Tilt from this side will be struck by the bleak and gloomy desert, which presents an aspect of the most forlorn and hopeless sterility.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The approach to Blair by Glen Tilt is best made from this side.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Castleton to BiiAiR-ATnoLL, BY Glen Tilt — 30 miles.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Two routes connect it with Perthshire — one through Glen Tilt, the other by the Spittal of Glenshee.

title: Days of the past;
author: Shand, Alexander Innes
snippet: Knapsack on shoulder, I was walking across from Braemar to Glen Tilt after a Braemar Gathering.

title: An American four-in-hand in Britain /
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: About three miles north of it rises Ben Vracky, and within easy distances are Glen Tilt, Bruar Water, the Pass of Killicrankie, Loch Tummel, the Falls of Tummel, and other places well worthy of a visit ; but as the Gay Charioteers' time was limited they could pay their respects to only a few of them.

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: His Athole guard (many of whom, with Struan at their head, were his peers in birth) would have died for him, not in word, but in deed ; and a young, capable shepherd, who might have pushed his fortune anywhere and to any length, was more than rewarded for living a solitary deer-keeper at the far-end of Glen Tilt, or up some to us nameless wild, where for months he saw no living thing but his dog and the deer, the eagles and the hill fox, the raven and the curlew, — by his £18 a year, his £3 for milk, his six bolls and a half of oatmeal, with his annual coat of gray tweed, his kilt and his hose, — so that he had the chance of a kind word or nod from the Duke, or, more blessed still, a friendly pipe with him in his hut, with a confidential  chat on the interests of the " Forest."

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: Up at all hours, out all day and all night, often without food, — with nothing but the unfailing pipe, — there he was, stalking the deer in Glen Tilt or across the Gaick moors, or rousing before daybreak the undaunted otter among the alders of the Earn, the Isla, or the Almond ; and if in his pursuit, which was fell as any hound's, he got his hand into the otter's grip, and had its keen teeth meeting in his palm, he let it have its will till the pack came up, — no flinching,  almost as if without the sense of pain.

title: Spare hours.

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack
author: Todd, George Eyre.
snippet: Through Glen Tilt, soutliAvards, apath leads to Blair Athole on the Garry, thirty miles away, Avhich isaccessible enouarh; and due AvestAvard, through the Feshie Forest, thereis another to Kingussie on the Spey; while a third goes northwardthrough the Larig Gruamach and the Rothiemurchus Forest toAviemore.

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack
author: Todd, George Eyre.
snippet: Pennant, on his famous tour, passed doAvn the Dee from Glen Tilt.
